title: Positive Thinking Is Not What CBT Is About!
description: This article explains the difference between positive thinking and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). Unlike simply “thinking positive”, CBT works with cognitive distortions and helps you change your behavior in an adaptive and realistic way. This approach relies on facts and analysis, which makes it effective for dealing with emotions and difficult life situations.

texts: You might ask: so do I just need to constantly think about good things? Close my eyes to problems, build a little “rainbow fence” around myself and repeat: “Everything is fine, everything is great”?
The connection between CBT and positive thinking is about the same as between a computer mouse and a field mouse: they sound similar, but in reality they belong to completely different worlds.
To be more precise: these approaches share one basic idea — our perception affects our emotions and choices. And that’s where the similarities end.
Positive thinking urges us to think positively; CBT teaches us to think rationally and adaptively, to test our ideas against facts and adjust them.
Positive thinking is the ability to keep your spirits up and see the good in any situation, genuinely believing that everything happens for the best.
Cognitive-behavioral therapy is aimed at identifying and correcting cognitive distortions (unhelpful thoughts and beliefs) and then changing behavior.

If the line between them still feels blurry, let’s clarify: positive thinking suggests looking for the good in any circumstances — a useful skill, but a risky one when it turns into a rigid rule of “think only positive thoughts”.
Reality includes pain, sadness, failure, and disappointment — and that’s part of life. Acknowledging what’s hard doesn’t mean you’re being “negative”.
When we mechanically replace everything “bad” with something “good”, reality drops out of the equation — and we end up doing ourselves a disservice.

quote.text: Positive thinking lets you do everything the wrong way while believing you’re doing it right.
quote.author: Steven Friesen

test.question: Which statement best describes the difference between positive thinking and CBT?
answers: Positive thinking and CBT both focus on looking for the positive in every life situation
Positive thinking and CBT both focus on changing behavior rather than thinking
Positive thinking suggests replacing all negative thoughts with positive ones, whereas CBT focuses on analyzing and correcting cognitive distortions
CBT encourages you to look for the good in every life situation, whereas positive thinking focuses on analyzing reality

texts: Imagine something difficult happens: you lose your job, get ill, or go through a painful breakup — situations where the pain is very real.
The positive-thinking approach will suggest replacing your feelings with optimistic formulas like: “Don’t think about the bad stuff, everything will definitely be fine!”

CBT, on the other hand, invites you to first notice your negative thoughts, check how well they fit the facts, look at evidence for and against them — and only then replace them with more rational and adaptive ones.

For example: “I don’t know for sure that everything will be fine — just as I don’t know for sure that everything will go wrong. There are at least three scenarios: the worst, the best, and the most realistic. I’ll think through my steps for each one, prepare for the worst, and hope for the best.”
You can feel the difference in approach, right?
The three-scenario technique is a very practical tool. We’ll devote the next chapter to it!

By looking at events from different angles, stepping away from the “all-or-nothing” mindset, and making our thinking more rational (rather than simply “positive”), we cope better with our emotions and with real-life challenges.
